statement.text: The ISSVA (International Society for the Study of Vascular Anomalies) classification divides vascular anomalies into two fundamental categories: vascular tumors (including hemangiomas that proliferate and involute) and vascular malformations (structural abnormalities present at birth that grow proportionally), with malformations further classified by the predominant vessel type involved.
statement.formal: ISSVA_Classification: Vascular_Anomalies = Vascular_Tumors(Hemangioma, etc.) | Vascular_Malformations(Capillary | Venous | Lymphatic | Arterial | AVM | Combined)

explanation.intuition: Before ISSVA, vascular birthmarks were confusingly called 'hemangiomas' regardless of type. ISSVA clarified that TRUE hemangiomas are tumors that grow rapidly then shrink - completely different from malformations that are abnormal vessels present at birth that never go away and grow with the child.
explanation.key_insight: The fundamental distinction between TUMORS (proliferative, may involute) and MALFORMATIONS (structural errors, never involute) guides all therapy. Infantile hemangiomas may be observed or treated with propranolol; vascular malformations require procedural intervention if symptomatic. This classification revolutionized management.
explanation.technical_details: ISSVA 2018 Classification: (1) Vascular Tumors - benign (infantile hemangioma, congenital hemangioma, tufted angioma), locally aggressive (kaposiform hemangioendothelioma), malignant (angiosarcoma). (2) Vascular Malformations - simple (capillary CM, lymphatic LM, venous VM, arteriovenous AVM, arteriovenous fistula AVF), combined (CVM, LVM, CLVM, CAVM, etc.), major named vessels, associated with other anomalies. Flow classification: low-flow (CM, LM, VM) vs high-flow (AVM, AVF). Genetic mutations increasingly identified: PIK3CA (CLOVES, LM, VM), GNAQ (CM), MAP2K1 (AVM). This classification determines imaging approach, treatment modality, and prognosis.

infantile_hemangioma.natural_history: Appears 1-4 weeks, rapid growth 0-12 months, involution 1-10 years

congenital_hemangioma.difference: Present and fully formed at birth (unlike infantile)

definition.@value: International classification system dividing vascular anomalies into tumors (proliferative) and malformations (structural), with malformations further classified by predominant vessel type and flow characteristics.

sources.title: ISSVA Classification for Vascular Anomalies
sources.organization: International Society for the Study of Vascular Anomalies

learning_objectives: Distinguish vascular tumors from vascular malformations
Classify malformations by vessel type and flow
Apply ISSVA classification to guide treatment selection
clinical_pearls: TUMOR (hemangioma) = proliferates then involutes; MALFORMATION = structural, never involutes
Infantile hemangioma is GLUT-1 positive - use to differentiate if unsure
AVM is HIGH-FLOW - warm, thrill, bruit; VM is LOW-FLOW - compressible, expands with Valsalva
PIK3CA mutations underlie many vascular malformations

medicalCode.description: Congenital malformation of peripheral vascular system, unspecified
